DDFD522859D44B1C8F46E83B0EBF6892.description: Examine how antisemitism may be expressed as hatred toward Jewish people, rhetorical, and physical manifestations directed toward a person, their property, or Jewish community institutions.

199E14307D73466FA474DB549B07B018.description: Explain why it is important for current and future generations to learn from the Shoah through eye-witness accounts and survivors’ testimony.

EF4C17A09266402AB1B8B930BFA9B531.description: Describe how Holocaust denial has helped contribute to the creation of contemporary propaganda against the State of Israel and the Jewish people.

4CF5D916E49142E0A84F9DB972A03A10.description: The student will describe the legacy of the Holocaust and antisemitism in the world today.

9771641F62664C869A9FFA8E4EF42B5F.description: exploitation of Western investment in China and scientific, academic, and industrial espionage.

E0226710E9FA45AAB1BD2E7D4FBDD6AF.description: social credit system to monitor the population, denial of access to schools, travel, banks, and other state institutions

F29165A265BB44318B31D55C58CE2CBC.description: continuing internal repression (e.g., Christians, Falun Gong, Hong Kong, Tibet, Xinjiang)

3438531B505E40F592D08EBEF8F529D8.description: rapid growth of the economy, government debt, dependence on exports, Belt and Road Initiative

27965555A0F24B7C8B2EBE864B7371B1.description: rise of Jiang Zemin and the introduction of the concept of a Socialist Market Economy

A093E887A86E4F28B08F16E573BC3A20.description: retirement of Deng Xiaoping following the Tiananmen Square massacre

39A2073748354F68B2D2B553D56427E3.description: Trace the rise of China to peer competitor with the United States, including the

B2F1ECA5AD7249A78C45F9D32B0CA9F5.description: Describe the causes and events of the Tiananmen Square Massacre, including suppression by the Chinese Communist Party and the continuing denial regarding the massacre.

358CB1CE690D4AC7AA2E93D2DA7880EF.description: The student will analyze the history of Communist China in the modern era.

5201BE8B36A2409F8D762F860DB389B9.description: Examine the dissolution of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the August Coup (e.g., rise of Boris Yeltsin and the pluralist movement, uprisings in Lithuania and Latvia, Gorbachev’s resignation, dissolution of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, declarations of independence of the now-former Soviet republics).

C97BE5A9888C4B8C859CD9064E486CEC.description: Describe the causes and impact of the Velvet Revolution in Czechoslovakia and the Christmas Revolution in Romania, including the trial and execution of Nicolae and Elena Ceaușescu.

8746D727F29D4714A234E18F6E23365D.description: Examine Gorbachev’s attempt to reform the Soviet Union, including the effects of perestroika and glasnost.

6F1BFD0D008942209EB9B675F738E5D8.description: Describe the decay and dissolution of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, including the effect of the Reagan Doctrine, American support for anti-communists in Afghanistan and Nicaragua, and diplomacy related to the Intermediate-Range Nuclear Forces Treaty (INF Treaty).

BA4619C3D51546439AFF223FF2CDDE0F.description: Examine how Marxism evolved after the West’s intellectual disillusionment with Soviet Communism and evaluate the role of Soviet dissidents, such as Boris Pasternak, Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, and Vladimir Bukovsky.

6A37544AB95F44B89814090F60ACCBF3.description: Examine the development of communism in the United States, including Soviet coordination of Western communist party tactics, communist front movements, and attempts to infiltrate and co-opt organized labor.

2EE557EE4EAE41AC82772EFF1AA9E287.description: Describe the rise of communism in Vietnam (e.g., successful communist revolt against French colonial rule, Land Reform Terror, Soviet and Chinese support for the North Vietnamese Communist forces, the fall of South Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia, and establishment of Cambodia’s genocidal dictatorship under Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge).

9A5C50811FC946FE864E77240A51AF02.description: Deng Xiaoping’s political and economic reforms.

4C62DF1D35584265A655E15561629FDC.description: China’s genocidal conquest of Tibet, Great Leap Forward, and Cultural Revolution

A490C5AA68DC4B70802D239DC0BD5119.description: Chinese Revolution (e.g., one-party dictatorship, collectivization, laogai prisons, Hundred Flowers Campaign, and Anti-Rightist Campaign).

3C940671988C45388CCDC02223E69386.description: establishment of the North Korean dictatorship

5D761C6F3DA34744BCA66AE29F3195D6.description: Communist leadership (e.g., Che Guevara, Fidel Castro, Mao Zedong, and Kim Il Sung)

566CFCE0E3564FBB8DF91FA45B742BA5.description: Trace the rise of communist influence in other regions of the world, including

3574A6DF65EB4F7EB67EDBA6DD91BE43.description: Explain the West’s response to communism in the early Cold War, including the policy of containment, the Truman Doctrine, the Marshall Plan, the Berlin Airlift, formation of NATO and the Warsaw Pact, escalation of atomic weapons. disarmament movements, and construction of the Berlin Wall.

2E6B893793BE46C99D44401CFB1F8E78.description: Examine the USSR’s occupation of Eastern Europe after World War II, including Soviet Communization of Eastern Europe, the coup d’etat in Czechoslovakia, chronic rebellions in the Eastern Bloc (e.g., East German Uprising, Hungarian Uprising, “Prague Spring” in Czechoslovakia, and “Solidarity” in Poland) and neutrality of Finland and Austria.

F038AC42B61945C189637A16F52145D2.description: The student will analyze significant events, policies, and experiences of the Cold War.

021014E8917A4DB4B046CD2313CE56A5.description: war policy (e.g., terror, ethnic cleansing, looting operations in conquered countries, and the occupation of Eastern Europe).

5790305CAC3647E5908CC4213E0F2D21.description: cooperation with Nazi Germany (e.g., Nazi-Soviet pact, Soviet annexations, population deportations, Winter War, Katyn massacre)

FFC8E368443C478FB8F23891CA962EAF.description: opposition to reform socialists that catalyzed the rise of fascist governments

579D9E91FC16465BA9FD95FECE65C441.description: support for foreign communist parties and popular fronts

08CB5399EB6F4EE1A1140D4A156115F5.description: Describe interwar Soviet foreign policy and the effect of World War II, including the

1EB3BB119006469BBA275A2BE731543B.description: mass murder of peasants (dekulakization campaign) and genocidal starvation of Ukrainians (Holodomor).

8F77B191478648549142579D4DF92C91.description: purges of the military officer corps and terror against the citizenry

E39D9E7D7E9D4C97B16CB0C7FA275E3E.description: cult of personality that glorified Stalin

ABDCD1EE41714B83A3075DD9788E886A.description: state-mandated atheism and the persecution of priests and religious believers

3C3F1C9B3B6B404F807B7EE7024C391B.description: requirement of internal passports to control people’s movements

0F35EBD624BB4C019104888C77B6E1EA.description: government seizure of privately owned industry and commerce

1B3DB2B49FA3418E9D9F310E9FBDBCBF.description: Describe the domestic policies of interwar Soviet Russia, including the

EE061693C2174E11B457965F716BD40F.description: Great Terror and the murder of foreign Communists living in the USSR

87F1CA2D21FD4D6F9E3921367059E2F0.description: collectivization and the First Five Year Plan

06D3BB05109A4A8EBEE3BB59C1A729BF.description: Examine the political history of interwar Soviet Russia, including the

4FD02069512246CD94BDB31496A1D0A6.description: The student will trace key events, policies, and experiences of life in the USSR prior to and during World War II.

B9568F7E8B30477A9C61D2390802FB43.description: Explain the effect of the Eichmann Trial on policy concerning crimes against humanity, capital punishment, accountability, the testimony of survivors, and acknowledgment of the international community.

DA6A3BD14AD9412C9FD25ACFA5DCF7F4.description: Analyze the international community’s efforts to hold perpetrators responsible for their involvement in the Shoah (Holocaust) including the purpose and outcomes of the Nuremberg Trials as they related to crimes against humanity, genocide, and jurisdictional issues.

350A07D902EC47A1BA0FA0D2B188ECCC.description: Examine the settlement patterns of Shoah (Holocaust) survivors after World War II, including immigration to the United States and other countries and the establishment of the modern State of Israel.

B577AFB8AAD3435ABF0C58CA1BB736B7.description: Explain how Allied Forces liberated camps, including the relocation and treatment of the survivors.

A9393626364B4A7B961D720CA4A4380D.description: Describe the origins, purpose, and conditions associated with various types of camps, including forced labor camps, concentration camps, transit camps, and death camps (e.g., Auschwitz-Birkenau, Sobibor, Treblinka).

E19ACE31B4B0475D89A4542D4A5A89DB.description: Explain the purpose of the Wannsee Conference and its role in the Final Solution.

99CDD932C67A4413B1FA286354F770F5.description: Explain how corporate complicity aided Nazi goals, including identification and record keeping, and the use of slave labor for war production.

65C81CBE3403493FBA1AEF8575379CA4.description: Explain the use of ghettos, including the displacement and deportation of Jews to ghettos, attempts at escape, and forms of resistance, exemplified by the Warsaw Ghetto Uprising.

71C29FFC509742B087F7FF685F76D8E0.description: Examine the role that bystanders, collaborators and perpetrators played in the implementation of Nazi policies against Jewish people and other targeted groups.

CF37A2FD71FF4858BF7A318310A04585.description: Explain the effect of Nazi policies on other targeted groups, including Roma-Sinti, Slavs, Jehovah’s Witnesses, political opponents, the physically and mentally disabled, and homosexuals.

B5B3A48F70E3478EB5E93B5311523EF0.description: Explain the Shoah (Holocaust) as the planned and systematic state-sponsored persecution and murder of European Jews by Nazi Germany and its collaborators.

71BE3C6F2A3F43488BA525D89B35279A.description: The student will examine the meaning and effects of the Shoah (Jewish Holocaust).

1B08CF03C70E476F8E051F9D68EC02F1.description: Identify Hitler’s motivations for the annexations of Austria and the Sudetenland, as well as the invasion of Poland.

0B4D9903ABA64FD4B54D9B6724278ADF.description: Analyze Hitler’s use of the Munich Pact to expand German territory and the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact to ensure the Soviet Union’s neutrality.

E9C9A06704444F608B13AEF0435C7C04.description: Examine the term “lebensraum” (living space) was an essential piece of Nazi ideology and explain how it led to territorial expansion and invasion.

399B13DE3E384559AC46245CCDF52C30.description: The student will analyze Nazi justification for territorial expansion.

145F98498CBE4886BAD18CB69FD2382D.description: Examine the choices and actions of individuals and groups defying Nazi policy at great personal ris

C4D3DD20C70449EF9BA734FFD314C96E.description: Describe how Jewish immigration was restricted by various nations and explain how the Kindertransport saved the lives of Jewish children.

8369E3D8F9224583B0F9804C10D76B92.description: Analyze the effects of Kristallnacht and how it became a watershed event in the transition from targeted persecution to open, public violence against Jews.

9BAB7814DF9A455185752557A3473574.description: Describe how the life of Jews deteriorated under the Third Reich through implementation of the Nuremberg Laws.

87B213520DD54B8A913CE5812D0A49F8.description: Examine how identification, legal, and economic status was used to perpetuate the Nazi ideology of the “Master Race” and target Jews.

4F6BCEF450944AB183AD76A2CE6517B9.description: Explain the Nazi concept of an Aryan race and how eugenics and pseudoscience racism provided a foundation for Nazi racial beliefs.

E11ABE6D7ED14EEF925FD5A303774AE3.description: The student will explain antisemitic ideology and actions undertaken by Nazi Germany.

8EBC5160C59E491C994B0F893D250A50.description: use of education and youth programs to indoctrinate young people into the Nazi ideology.

66D535CF35DA4A43A12EC7B7C889D490.description: elimination of opposing views through book burnings, censorship, and state control over the media

E1EC23BDB80E4363AD2E861D9015C868.description: use of various forms of propaganda to indoctrinate the German population

773EE3FB665F4381B0AA5BEEA84E7153.description: efforts of the Sturmabteilung (SA), the Schutzstaffel (SS), the Wehrmacht, and the Gestapo to assist Hitler in gaining and maintaining power

5DEAF6398B0C4AC98E476B6495E5F065.description: Explain how the National Socialist German Workers’ Party, or Nazi Party, grew into a mass movement and maintained power through totalitarian means, including the

F3604B00D2114B2191AA3228263EB51E.description: Night of the Long Knives (Rohm Purge).

9E9212C92A8C4A00B2C3C661863B1860.description: arrest of Hitler and the writings of Mein Kampf

824794C144354E249EF86461AB613208.description: Trace the significant events that led to Adolf Hitler’s rise to power, including the

15BA85C3EC974F98B3A3863C93992784.description: Analyze how the Nazi regime utilized and built on historical antisemitism to create a common enemy of the Jews in order to gain power.

F406A38D8AD24F359908C207A61389FC.description: Explain how events during the Weimar Republic led to the rise of Nazism (e.g., Ruhr Crisis, hyperinflation, Great Depression, Dawes Plan, failures of the Weimar Republic).

116894935E4F410EAD4408AC48F6B96D.description: Examine German culpability, reparations, and military downsizing as effects of the Treaty of Versailles.

919A1AE6B0EB4B6DAB4B8F696012A26A.description: The student will analyze the origins of the National Socialist German Workers’ Party (Nazi) regime.

CAC7B6462D534D18ACDE816C4EB84B55.description: formal establishment of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR).

0D9D9274D1B8443CB1BB41BBF0B1F87D.description: impact of the beliefs and policies of Vladimir Lenin

D1683CD73B5545BCB28549AFD647EBD0.description: brutal repression (e.g., expropriating private industry, rationing food, mass famine, suppression of strikes, expropriation of the Church, murder of priests)

C79318449B1E4750BD5585EDA198F2EC.description: Civil War, the Red Terror, and the Kronstadt Rebellion

EAB18AB88EB24631A582D7EB6D6ECC41.description: October Revolution, the Bolshevik seizure of power, and the establishment of one-party dictatorship

EFD7405591D44737A0739B185844906C.description: February Revolution and the Provisional (Kerensky) government

C9BA67CBE7354B23ABE4D27171CA895B.description: Trace the significant events of the Russian Revolution, including the

18227A9E5ECA47A7911E2FFBA8DC8CBF.description: Examine the response of communist and socialist leaders and parties in Europe and the United States to changing conditions created by the First World War (e.g., repudiation of nationalism, pacifist movements, the Espionage and Sedition Acts, role of wartime politics, formation of post-World War I national socialism).

452674D6DE6D4A348ACEFC55058303E2.description: The student will analyze the effect of World War I on Communist and socialist movements.

C0C963BA4EDD4A1A80626A6EE51F67D6.description: Describe the social reforms that responded to the intellectual and political challenge of communist and socialist parties (e.g., child labor laws, retirement pensions, accident and health insurance, expanded voting rights, establishment of unions, emancipation of Russian serfs).

7B2BC12FBFDA45E99B41026AD871D6CC.description: Explain the rise of the Mensheviks, Bolsheviks, and Socialist Revolutionaries in Tsarist Russia, the 1905 Revolution, and revolutionary terrorism.

DAAE438F5E2842E693C5B6502A913400.description: Trace the rise and limited appeal of the Industrial Workers of the World and the Socialist Party in the United States.

F4D7FA152FD84B7C910F43A8FBB069FD.description: Describe the Second International and its efforts to impose Marxist theory on the socialist parties of Europe, the United States, and Japan.

AEB0E9476AE644D3B9E9D1E5746F8525.description: France’s Paris Commune and the rise of the Section Française de l’Internationale Ouvrière

86E09F1297814F6188912E2399FD43F9.description: Germany’s Social Democratic Party and anti-socialist laws

B1899C839D154BECAED9C67A1D904FEA.description: Identify political responses to Communist and socialist political parties in Europe, including

45E89488FD2A44A8ADE661CB42E3569B.description: The student will examine responses to Communist and socialist political parties prior to the First World War.

F1E35EEC6F50428DAD8492F12A0BD2D6.description: Describe how state ownership of means of production, including centralized economic planning, leads to an authoritarian state which restricts individual freedoms.

65944B911CD04BA68C675834C5E96C3E.description: Explain how violent revolution tends to undermine the rule of law and may empower those more capable of oppression.

D828B4A1C86649DAA58C79F3ED494C6A.description: Examine the criticisms of the ideas of Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels.

6A68C040E69A4727A8FC3439E40CCBC2.description: Explain the proposition that violent revolution is needed to overthrow the oppressive classes and abolish exploitative institutions.

3EBCE30D6CC04887808C7E78ED2A4AEA.description: Describe Marxist claims related to the individual and religion, by examining the idea that law and morality are mere “bourgeois prejudices” and religion an “opiate of the masses.”

66EF5757DE80483F9A96721C03DF337E.description: Describe the idea that private property is exploitative, based on selfishness, and results in inequality.

D45D0355B2D34E708D8AB78160E9ABF2.description: Analyze the proposition that industrialization and free trade had alienated workers from the fruits of their labors.

3A6F808FE1464D80927E94CD2EE27F9A.description: Examine the claim that private enterprise is exploitative and inequality the fault of capitalism.

67F3AAF0846B4E9F93DFAC881BB06642.description: Explain the socio-economic ideas of Marx and Engels as outlined in their treatise The Communist Manifesto, including the claim known as “dialectical materialism,” which proposed that history must be viewed through the lens of “class struggles” between “oppressor and oppressed.”

826BDE77DC4544B89AB4D4C8274E3B7B.description: Describe the growth of reformist political movements and the growth of radical and revolutionary political movements, including anarchism, socialism, and communism.

B16A109CA4FA4B8680DD3D77E291EE10.description: The student will analyze the effects of the Industrial Revolution on Europe’s economy and society.

58DEA4F7FBE8492686F0DA0342C59F4F.description: Construct presentations or products for a designated audience, using research and reasoning to enhance understanding of a topic or issue.

6945C9DCBE0445719CBB150BB6B3C6A0.description: Integrate quotes and summaries of research findings into written products while avoiding plagiarism.

B0543F9ACDE7447AA6E227D412F83090.description: Develop self-generated theses or claims related to independent research and investigations using credible and relevant sources.

6ECA676F8BA845C38315DF55AD5CBEE5.description: Engage in authentic research to acquire, refine, and share knowledge through written presentations and products.

1CA67219B59F4E82BA82D40B9299E0C1.description: Compose argumentative written products, including a precise claim as distinguished from opposing claims, organizing logical reasoning, and providing credible evidence to develop an argument.

AE5D265C739044B08AC08673688F8E55.description: Compose informative essays and written products, developing a thesis, citing and incorporating evidence from multiple sources and maintaining an organized, formal structure.

62BE9EA50EFA4FEF9DFA77728DC19CB2.description: Summarize and paraphrase, integrate evidence, and cite sources to create written products, research projects, and presentations for multiple purposes related to social studies content.

354A22EB0F954933A03A79B360D196FD.description: The student will develop a variety of evidence- based written products designed for multiple purposes.

754E6DED5FA24CE5AF0B3494C1573F77.description: Actively listen, evaluate, and analyze a speaker’s message, asking questions while engaged in collaborative discussions about social studies topics and texts.

C2258C304C264C16890C2B096B43C041.description: Evaluate the author’s point of view, potential bias, and how authors can reach different conclusions regarding the same issue.

E39F9517847A433F9DD3D3F5FCCA3B27.description: Evaluate the extent to which historical or cultural perspectives affect an author’s stated or implied purpose.

109E90FEF802430C9CC44587A2F5A558.description: Apply critical reading and thinking skills to interpret, evaluate, and respond to a variety of complex texts and perspectives.

25A699409530428EABC237BAFFC1D5CD.description: Analyze information from visual, oral, digital, and interactive texts (e.g., maps, charts, images, political cartoons, videos, artwork) in order to draw conclusions and defend arguments.

1EC85BD9F07D4209A5E4D6F4A771FFD7.description: Cite specific textual evidence to support analysis of primary and secondary sources, evaluating features such as author, date, and origin of information.

DC01BD4DB72C47A8B27BC8249E6DA9BD.description: Comprehend, evaluate, and synthesize textual sources to acquire and refine knowledge in the social studies.

FF379CEDD912472098DE069A4AC0DAE8.description: The student will engage in critical, active reading of primary and secondary sources related to social studies concepts.

92C97B85D5C44DD9A6A93E299CE76014.description: Evaluate the impact, both intended and unintended, of government policies on market outcomes at national and global levels, past and present.

E84C9696DF64451D83684A81140A9DD1.description: Construct arguments using a combination of evidence regarding solutions used by nations to address historical or contemporary economic issues.

76F6DAB89B2D471DB760C01E2EDD8746.description: Evaluate economic data from charts and graphs, noting trends and making predictions.

78213A0C97224AEA9FE4EE5C1314C5B6.description: Identify the principles of economic systems and develop an understanding of the benefits of a market system in local, national, and global settings.

538F851833ED432EB049F66D723854A8.description: Evaluate the extent to which political and economic decisions have had significant impact on human and physical environments of various places and regions.

1B1951A0DDEC402B86857B3C68931E83.description: Compare and analyze complex maps and mapping technologies to analyze spatial patterns of human and physical environments, explaining relationships between the environment and events, past and present.

9C644B54495E472CB9EA7062B8135EB1.description: Actively engage in asking and answering geographic questions by acquiring, organizing, and analyzing multiple sources of data and information about the world’s past and present.

81B8D004F413482E913129F88B25868C.description: Demonstrate a mastery of geographic concepts and the use of geographic tools to understand the impact of geography on the past and present.

EFDE8C095C634FC98B2FA2C0D5E8B87A.description: Evaluate how multiple, complex events are shaped by unique circumstances of time and place; construct and interpret parallel timelines.

B730B717771B46EBAEE113B2C11FA157.description: Analyze complex and interacting factors that influence multiple perspectives during different historical eras and contemporary events.

ABE3DCEC3D61402082A859D325A49C03.description: Gather and evaluate the usefulness of various formats of evidence for specific inquiry, analyzing the broader historical context, and assessing potential bias and credibility of sources.

13BEA75F40A040EB847AAD97F1E8FEC8.description: Develop skills which demonstrate an understanding of historical events and the people who shaped our history.

F5C7E154322048DA841D0706BB6278D8.description: Analyze the impact of constitutions, laws, treaties, and international agreements, by comparing how various governmental powers and responsibilities have changed over time.

BB862E4BEB704EB48734B40334D9809D.description: Evaluate the impact of the structure and powers exercised by governmental systems on public policy, using historical and contemporary examples.

CCF9792F65FB406E9E8D975C88463EC7.description: Evaluate various significant documents from the United States and other nations to compare civic virtues and principles of political systems.

3DE863C13D6240B48069CAC27BE9AB8A.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the principles of government, the benefits of democratic systems, and their responsibilities as citizens.

8AE579CA3BC1460F9BA531915F354212.description: The student will use interdisciplinary tools to acquire, apply, and evaluate content understanding of the four strands of social studies.

395CA14E87F04C1EBC8AC094C20E955F.description: Demonstrate understanding of content through the development of self-driven inquiries and the completion of multi-staged, authentic tasks and assessments.

3FCEF12084774CD09E76CB8F4946AC0F.description: Reinforce critical thinking by evaluating and challenging ideas and assumptions, analyzing and explaining inconsistencies in reasoning.

AF52F66F863E4B38A55AD41C6CA42DA1.description: Evaluate points of agreement and disagreement from reliable information and expert interpretations used to answer supporting questions related to content knowledge.

3CFCEBF56BCE4C38B386DA7A516A6DC7.description: Develop, investigate, and evaluate plausible answers to essential questions that reflect enduring understandings across time, real world circumstances, and social studies disciplines.

21247EDDEB204B7F8C94EF224D19C006.description: Develop practices which demonstrate an understanding that social studies involves the evaluation of evidence.

3A0CCE5416FB4C5B8A30E155AE5148AB.description: Gather and evaluate information regarding complex problems, assessing individual and collective actions taken to address them.

4C163AD3764D45D98BB94DB30002058F.description: Engage in a range of deliberative and democratic processes to develop strategies to address authentic, real-world problems in community and out-of-school contexts.

858D12DD9FCB4E47ADBBC939615465AD.description: Evaluate the impact of perspectives, civil discourse, and democratic principles on addressing civic issues.

9041F42165B040B8890B9E22936F628B.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the virtue of civil discourse to analyze and address real- world problems.

7AC0E58459D0452A8D9498957E2E7954.description: The student will apply critical thinking skills to address authentic civic issues.
